title: First home buyers: WA borrows more for first homes than any other state
text:
WA first home buyers are among the biggest borrowers in the country, with nearly 60 per cent of buyers borrowing more than 90 per cent of the cost of their home.
The number of WA borrowers is about 10 per cent higher than the national average.
Mortgage Choice data shows WA first home owners are borrowing more than ever to get into their new digs — with 80 per cent of buyers now relying on lenders mortgage insurance.
Mortgage Choice head of corporate affairs Jessica Darnbrough said many first home buyers didn’t realise that LMI was to protect the bank, not the buyer, in the case of mortgage default.
She said avoiding LMI could be a major way to reduce the cost of a loan and said it could be done through a parental guarantor, borrowing money for the deposit or saving a bigger deposit.
Finder.com.au money expert Michelle Hutchinson agreed buyers should do what they could to avoid LMI and said first home buyers should consider deals that came with an offset savings account or a free redraw facility.
But RateCity finance analyst Peter Arnold warned buyers to be wary of banks offering incentives such as a particularly low interest rate for the first year.
“First home buyers should be wary of hidden costs, such as withdrawal charges and other fees,” he said.
FINANCE FAST FACTS
L enders Mortgage Insurance
A one-off fee added to your overall loan to protect the bank in the instance you default on your mortgage. Banks charge this to those borrowing 80 per cent or more. The only way to avoid it is by having a deposit of 20 per cent plus or a parental guarantor.
Offset Account
A transaction account linked to your loan. The credit balance of your transaction is offset daily against your outstanding loan balance, reducing the interest payable. This can be handy as it allows you to take money in and out, while also limiting the interest you have to pay. Watch out for loans that charge withdrawal fees.
First Home Owners Grant
The State Government currently offers a $10,000 grant for first home builders and a $3000 grant for existing properties. However, before the end of the year they will cut the $10,000 grant to $7000 and scrap the $3000 grant. If you buy now, you are still eligible.
Stamp Duty
Buyers pay the State Government when they purchase land or a property. First home buyers are exempt if they purchase a house for less than $430,000.
Home Loan Application Fee
A bank fee when you apply for a home loan that varies between banks.
